title: EE recalls Power Bars after portable phone charger explodes

Wed, Aug 5, 2015, 14:38 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 52 mins EE recalls Power Bars after portable phone charger explodes By James Titcomb | Telegraph â€“ 30 minutes ago 70.00 -1.00 
Mobile network behind Orange (Taiwan OTC: 4554.TWO - news ) and T-Mobile tells customers to return chargers it gave away for free 
EE is recalling hundreds of thousands of Power Bars after several of the portable battery packs had defects that led to overheating, and in at least one case exploding. 
The UK's biggest mobile operator texted customers on Wednesday to say it was recalling the devices, which EE has given out for free to its customers. 
Last week, a medical student in Aberdeen sustained burns on her hand after her bedroom caught fire when one of the chargers exploded in her bag. 
EE said it was recalling the bars marked "E1-06" after discovering "a very small number of cases" of overheating. 
"Important safety issue: In a very small number of cases EE Power Bars marked E1-06 have been overheating," it told customers. 
It said the devices could pose a fire risk, and urged people to return them to stores. It is currently investigating the incident and plans to give customers new bars after that, although it said the investigation could take weeks. 
Models with other serial numbers have not seen any overheating issues, the company said. 
The Power Bar acts as a battery pack when users are out and about and low on battery. It contains a USB port to which one can affix a charging cable, and claims to have enough capacity to fully charge a smartphone once. 
Inside the Power Bar is a typical lithium-ion battery, the type used in almost all of today's portable gadgets. Although overheating is rare, small failures can cause a chain reaction that leads to explosions. 
Around 1.5 million Power Bars have been made available, although only some are affected by the recall. 
EE announced the Power Bar scheme , which gives EE, Orange and T-Mobile customers the portable chargers, in April. It has faced huge demand for them, which has limited supply at times.
